articles.headline: The Limits of a Europe Whole and Free
articles.snippet: Vladimir Putin sets down a marker in Ukraine. Does the West have the means to stop him?
articles.abstract: Vladimir Putin sets down a marker in Ukraine. Does the West have the means to stop him?
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the prime minister of Lithuania — and Lithuania knows something of life in Moscow’s imperium — President Vladimir V. Putin’s rambling dismissal of Ukrainian statehood, used to justify sending Russian troops into the eastern part of that state, “put Kafka and Orwell to shame.”

articles.headline: Russia’s Moves in Ukraine Unsettle Energy Companies and Prices
articles.snippet: Oil and gas prices are up, and Western energy giants with operations and investments in Russia could find it harder to keep doing business there.
articles.abstract: Oil and gas prices are up, and Western energy giants with operations and investments in Russia could find it harder to keep doing business there.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s recognition of two breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine could threaten important investments of Western oil giants and further drive up global energy prices in the next few weeks.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Global Banks Poised for Turmoil as West Hits Russia With Sanctions
articles.snippet: The U.S. and Britain are aiming to throttle Russia’s access to foreign capital. But things could get complicated for the entire global financial system.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and Britain are aiming to throttle Russia’s access to foreign capital. But things could get complicated for the entire global financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global banks are bracing for the ripple effects of harsh new financial and economic sanctions against Russia intended to hobble its economy and restrict its access to foreign capital.
articles.byline: By Lananh Nguyen and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Germany Responds to Russia, Halting Nord Stream 2 Pipeline
articles.snippet: After Russia ordered its military into Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz suspended a natural gas pipeline connecting Germany to Russia.
articles.abstract: After Russia ordered its military into Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz suspended a natural gas pipeline connecting Germany to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As recently as December, Olaf Scholz, the German chancellor, considered the new natural gas pipeline connecting Russia to the German seacoast a strictly “private-sector project” that had no role in political discussions.

articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Impose Sanctions on Russia as Biden Condemns ‘Invasion’ of Ukraine
articles.snippet: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that more sanctions would follow if he did not withdraw his forces and engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.
articles.abstract: President Biden warned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia that more sanctions would follow if he did not withdraw his forces and engage in diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies on Tuesday swiftly imposed economic sanctions on Russia for what President Biden denounced as the beginning of an “invasion of Ukraine,” unveiling a set of coordinated punishments as Western officials confirmed that Russian forces had begun crossing the Ukrainian border.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Richard Pérez-Peña, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: Climate Fears on Back Burner as Fuel Costs Soar and Russia Crisis Deepens
articles.snippet: Energy security has gained prominence while the conflict in Ukraine raises concerns over the possible interruption in the supply of oil and natural gas.
articles.abstract: Energy security has gained prominence while the conflict in Ukraine raises concerns over the possible interruption in the supply of oil and natural gas.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was only three months ago that world leaders met at the Glasgow climate summit and made ambitious pledges to reduce fossil fuel use. The perils of a warming planet are no less calamitous now, but the debate about the critically important transition to renewable energy has taken a back seat to energy security as Russia — Europe’s largest energy supplier — threatens to start a major confrontation with the West over Ukraine while oil prices are climbing toward $100 a barrel.

articles.headline: Fed Up With Google, Conspiracy Theorists Turn to DuckDuckGo
articles.snippet: The embrace by some conservative influencers and conspiracy theorists is part of a broader effort to shift people away from Big Tech.
articles.abstract: The embrace by some conservative influencers and conspiracy theorists is part of a broader effort to shift people away from Big Tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: How China Under Xi Jinping Is Turning Away From the World
articles.snippet: Global engagement has helped the nation prosper. But now, its leader seems intent on recasting the meeting of minds and cultures as a zero-sum clash.
articles.abstract: Global engagement has helped the nation prosper. But now, its leader seems intent on recasting the meeting of minds and cultures as a zero-sum clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: The miracle of modern China was built on global connections, a belief that sending young people, companies and future leaders to soak up the outside world was the route from impoverishment to power. Now, emboldened by its transformation, the country is shunning the influences and ideas that nourished its rise.

articles.headline: European Sanctions Target Putin’s Inner Circle
articles.snippet: The measures, coinciding with new U.S. moves, were designed to hurt individuals but not average Russians. But more will follow if Russia fully invades Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The measures, coinciding with new U.S. moves, were designed to hurt individuals but not average Russians. But more will follow if Russia fully invades Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The list included some of the Kremlin’s highest ranking officials, the top Russian military leadership, senior bank executives, a prominent news anchor, the head of a global television network and a Russian businessman with links to a mercenary group.

articles.headline: More Trouble for a Troubled Market
articles.snippet: Whether you call it a correction or a panic attack, a stock market that was already becoming shaky has been roiled by Russia’s hostilities toward Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Whether you call it a correction or a panic attack, a stock market that was already becoming shaky has been roiled by Russia’s hostilities toward Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. stock market has been stumbling since the beginning of the year. Now, Russia’s escalating conflict with Ukraine is adding considerably to the market’s problems.
